text: These are the words that Moses spoke to all Israel in the area beyond the Jordan, in the wilderness, in the Arabah opposite Suph, between Paran on one side and Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Di Zahab on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: (It is an eleven-day journey from Horeb to Kadesh Barnea by the Mount Seir road.)
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fortieth year, in the eleventh month, on the first of the month, Moses spoke to the people of Israel everything that the Lord had commanded him concerning them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was after he had defeated Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and he had defeated Og king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth, at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the area east of the Jordan, in the land of Moab, Moses took on the task of explaining clearly this law as follows. This is what he said:
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God spoke to us at Horeb. He said, “You have stayed at this mountain long enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: Turn in the other direction, start traveling, and go to the hill country of the Amorites and to all the people living in the Arabah, in the hill country, in the Shephelah, and in the Negev, and in the coastland by the sea (the land of the Canaanites) and the Lebanon range, up to the Great River (the River Euphrates).
speaker: Narrator

text: Look now, I have given you the land that is ahead of you. Go and take possession of the land that the Lord swore to give to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, promising to give it to them and to their descendants after them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said to you at that time, “I am not able to carry you by myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God has increased your number, and here you are today, as numerous as the stars in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord, the God of your fathers, add to you a thousand times as many as you are now, and may he bless you, just as he promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But how can I manage by myself to carry the burden that you have become and the load that you are—especially your disputes?
speaker: Narrator

text: Provide for yourselves, tribe by tribe, men who are wise and perceptive and with known ability, and I will appoint them as your leaders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you answered me, “What you propose to do is good.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the heads of your tribes, men who were wise and of known ability, and I appointed them as heads over you, commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds and commanders of fifties and commanders of tens, as well as officers for your tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave these orders to your judges at that time: “Listen to disputes among your brothers, and judge righteously between a man and his brother Israelite, as well as with the alien who resides with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not show partiality in judgment. Provide a hearing for the small and the great alike. Do not be motivated by fear of any person, because judgment belongs to God. Any case that is too difficult for you, bring it before me and I will hear it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I gave you orders at that time about everything that you should do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we journeyed from Horeb, and we walked through that whole vast and terrifying wilderness that you saw on the road to the hill country of the Amorites, as the Lord our God had commanded us to do. When we came to Kadesh Barnea,
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, “You have come to the hill country of the Amorites, which the Lord our God is giving us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look now, the Lord your God has given you the land ahead of you. Go up, take possession of it, as the Lord, the God of your fathers, has said to you. Do not be afraid and do not be overwhelmed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of you approached me and said, “Let us send out some of our men so that they can scout the land for us and bring us a report about the route that we should take and the cities that we will reach.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The plan seemed good to me, so I selected from you twelve men, one man from each tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out and went up to the hill country and came to the area of the Valley of Eshcol and spied on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took in their hands some of the fruit of the land and brought it back to us and brought us a report that said, “The land that the Lord our God is giving us is good.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Still you were not willing to go up, and you rebelled against the order of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You complained in your tents and said, “Because the Lord hates us, he brought us out of the land of Egypt to hand us over to the Amorites so they could destroy us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are we going? Our brothers have made our hearts melt by saying, ‘People there are stronger and taller than we are! There are large cities with fortified walls up to the skies! Also, we have seen the descendants of Anak there!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said to you, “Do not be overwhelmed and do not be afraid of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God, who is going ahead of you, will fight for you, exactly as he did for you in Egypt, right before your very eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: and just as he did in the wilderness, where you saw that the Lord your God carried you as a man carries his son, on the entire way that you walked until you came to this place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet even with this, you did not believe the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: who went ahead of you on the journey to search out a place for you to camp. He showed you the way that you should travel, by fire during the night and by a cloud during the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord heard the tone of your words, he was angry, and he swore an oath:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Not one of these people from this evil generation will see the good land that I swore to give to your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: except Caleb son of Jephunneh. He will see it, and I will give the land on which he walked to him and his children, because he has fully followed the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was angry with me too because of you. He said, “You also will not enter there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joshua son of Nun, who is standing before you, will enter there. Strengthen him, because he will lead Israel to possess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your toddlers, who you said would become plunder of war, and your children, who today do not yet know good and evil, will enter there. I will give it to them and they will take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, turn around and travel into the wilderness toward the Red Sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you answered me, “We have sinned against the Lord. We will go up and fight, just as the Lord our God commanded us to do.” So each man among you strapped on his weapons of war, and you thought it would be easy to go up to the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord instructed me: “Say to them, ‘Do not go up and fight, because I will not be among you to keep you from being struck down by your enemies.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I spoke to you, but you did not listen. You rebelled against the command of the Lord and acted presumptuously by going up to the hill country anyway.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Amorites living in the hill country went out to meet you. They pursued you like bees, and they struck you down in Seir all the way to Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you returned and you cried out before the Lord, but the Lord did not pay attention to the noise you made. He did not listen to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you stayed in Kadesh many days—those well-known days that you stayed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we turned and traveled toward the wilderness on the road to the Red Sea, as the Lord had told me, and we traveled for many days to get around the area of Mount Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You have been traveling around this mountainous region long enough. Turn north
speaker: Narrator

text: and command the people, ‘You are about to pass through the territory of your brothers, the people of Esau, who are living in Seir, and they will be afraid of you. So be very careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not wage war against them because I am not going to give you any of their land, not even an area the size of a footprint, because I have given the Mount Seir region to Esau as a possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may buy food from them with money so you can eat, and you may purchase water from them with money so you can drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God has blessed you in all the work of your hands. He knows your trek through this vast wilderness. These forty years the Lord your God has been with you. You have not lacked anything.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we passed by the territory of our brothers, the people of Esau, who were living in Seir. After leaving the Arabah Road, Elat, and Ezion Geber behind us, we turned and we traveled along the road of the Wilderness of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Do not be hostile toward Moab and do not wage war against them in battle, because I am not going to give you any of their land as a possession, since I have given Ar to the people of Lot as a possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Emites formerly lived in it, a strong, numerous people and tall like the Anakites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They, like the Anakites, are also considered to be Rephaim, but the Moabites call them Emites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Horites also lived in Seir formerly, but the people of Esau took possession of their land and destroyed them from their midst. They settled there in their place, just as Israel did in the land that the Lord gave to them as their possession.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told us: “Now get ready and cross the Zered Canyon.” So we crossed over the Zered Canyon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time that we traveled from Kadesh Barnea until we crossed over the Zered Canyon was thirty-eight years, until that whole generation of fighting men were eliminated from the camp, just as the Lord had sworn to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes indeed, the hand of the Lord was against them to destroy them from the camp until they were eliminated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as soon as all those fighting men were eliminated from the people by their death,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord spoke to me:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Today you are going to cross the border of Moab at Ar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come near the people of Ammon, do not be hostile toward them and do not wage war against them, because I am not going to give any of the land of the people of Ammon to you as a possession, since I have given it to the people of Lot as a possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (It also is considered to be the land of the Rephaim. The Rephaim lived in it formerly, but the Ammonites call them Zamzumites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are a strong and numerous people and as tall as the Anakites. But the Lord destroyed the Rephaim from among the Ammonites. The Ammonites took possession of their land and lived there in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had done the same things for the people of Esau, who live in Seir, when he destroyed the Horites before them, and they took possession of their land and settled there in their place and remain there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Caphtorites, who came out of Caphtor, destroyed the Avvites who were living in villages as far as Gaza and settled in their place.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord told us: “Get ready to travel and cross over the Arnon Canyon. See, I have given into your hands Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and his land. Start to take possession of it and wage war against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day I will begin to put dread and fear of you on the faces of the people everywhere under heaven, so that they will hear reports about you and they will tremble, and they will be shaking because of you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I sent messengers from the Wilderness of Kedmoth to Sihon king of Heshbon with an offer of peace. I said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us pass through your land. We will proceed only on the road. We will not turn aside to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: You can sell us food in exchange for money so we can eat, and you can give us water in exchange for money so we can drink. Only let us pass through on foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: as did the people of Esau living in Seir and the Moabites living in Ar, until we can cross over the Jordan into the land that the Lord our God is giving us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon king of the Amorites was not willing to let us pass through on the road, because the Lord your God gave him a stubborn attitude by making his heart obstinate, in order to give him over into your hands, as is now the case today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Look now, I have begun to give you Sihon and his land. Start taking action to take possession of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Sihon and all of his people went out to meet us in battle at Jahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God gave him to us, and we struck him down, as well as his sons and all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we captured each of his cities at that time. We devoted each city to destruction, with the men, women, and children. We did not leave a survivor.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took only the livestock as plunder for ourselves, as well as the spoils of war from the cities that we captured.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Aroer, which is on the edge of the Arnon Canyon, from the city that is in the canyon, all the way up to Gilead, there was not a city that was out of reach for us. The Lord our God gave us everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was only the land of the people of Ammon that you did not approach: the land along both sides of the Jabbok Canyon, the cities of the hill country, and everything that the Lord our God had forbidden us to take.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then we turned and went up on the road to Bashan, and Og the king of Bashan came out to confront us. He and all his people came for war at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to me, “Do not be afraid of him, because I have given him into your hands, as well as all of his people and his land. Do to him as you did to Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived at Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord our God gave into our hands also Og king of Bashan and all his people. We struck them down until they had no survivor remaining.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we took all of his cities at that time. There was not a city that we did not take from them—sixty cities, the whole area of Argob, the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these were fortified cities with high walls, gates, and bars, besides very many small unwalled towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: We devoted them to destruction, just as we had done to Sihon king of Heshbon. There was a total destruction of every city, of men, women, and children,
speaker: Narrator

text: but all of the cattle and the plunder of the cities we took as spoils for ourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: So at that time we took the land out of the hands of the two kings of the Amorites who were east of the Jordan, from the Arnon Canyon to Mount Hermon.
speaker: Narrator

text: (The Sidonians call Hermon Sirion, but the Amorites call it Senir.)
speaker: Narrator

text: We took all the cities of the tableland and all of Gilead and all of Bashan, up to Salecah and Edrei, cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Only Og king of Bashan had remained from what was left of the Rephaim. His bed, a bed of iron, is it not in Rabbah of the people of Ammon? Its length is thirteen feet, and its width is six feet, according to the standard measure.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So we took possession of this land at that time. I gave to Reuben and to Gad the land starting at Aroer, which is at the Arnon Canyon, and half of the hill country of Gilead, as well as its cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave to the half tribe of Manasseh the remainder of Gilead and all of Bashan, the kingdom of Og, all the territory of Argob (all that part of Bashan is called the land of the Rephaim).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jair, the descendant of Manasseh, took all the territory of Argob up to the border of the Geshurites and the Ma’acathites, and he named the villages of Bashan after himself, Havvoth Jair, as they are called to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave Gilead to Makir.
speaker: Narrator

text: To the Reubenites and to the Gadites I gave the land of Gilead from the Arnon Canyon (that is, from the middle of the canyon), which served as one of their borders, up to the Jabbok Canyon, which served as their border with the people of Ammon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also the Arabah and the Jordan served as their border from the Sea of Kinneret to the Sea of the Arabah, that is, the Salt Sea, under the slopes of Pisgah on the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave you a command at that time: “The Lord your God gave you this land as a possession. All of your soldiers, armed for battle, are to cross over before your brother Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only your wives and your children and your livestock (I know that you have a lot of livestock) may stay in your cities that I have given you,
speaker: Narrator

text: until the Lord gives rest to your brothers as he has to you, and they also have taken possession of the land that the Lord your God is giving them on the other side of the Jordan. After that you may return, each man to his possession that I have given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I also gave a command to Joshua at that time: “With your own eyes you have been observing everything that the Lord your God has done to these two kings. The Lord will do the same to all the kingdoms to which you are crossing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be afraid of them, because the Lord your God himself is fighting for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I also begged the favor of the Lord at that time:
speaker: Narrator

text: “My Lord God, you have begun to show your servant your greatness and your strong hand. Indeed, what god in heaven or on earth is there that has done anything like your works and your mighty deeds?
speaker: Narrator

text: Let me cross over, please, and let me see the good land on the other side of the Jordan—this good hill country and the mountains of Lebanon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was furious with me because of you, and he did not listen to me but said to me, “Enough from you! Do not continue to speak to me anymore about this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go up to the top of Pisgah and lift up your eyes toward the west and the north and the south and the east. Take a good look, because you will not be crossing over this Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: But commission Joshua for duty and strengthen him and encourage him, because he will cross over in front of these people, and he will enable them to take possession of the land that you will only see.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we stayed in the valley opposite Beth Peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, Israel, listen to the statutes and the ordinances that I am teaching you, and carry them out so that you may live and so that you may enter the land that the Lord, the God of your fathers, is giving to you and take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add to the word that I am commanding you, and do not subtract from it, so that you keep the commandments of the Lord your God that I am commanding you.
speaker: Narrator

text: With your own eyes you have been observing what the Lord did at Baal Peor. Indeed, the Lord your God destroyed from among you every man who followed the Baal of Peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all of you, who are clinging to the Lord your God, are still alive today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Note well now, I have taught you statutes and ordinances, as the Lord my God commanded me, so that you may carry them out also in the land that you are entering to take as a possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep them and put them into practice, because in this way your wisdom and your understanding will be recognized by all the people who hear about all these statutes; and they will say, “This great nation is certainly a wise and understanding people,”
speaker: Narrator

text: because what other great nation is there that has a god as close to it as the Lord our God is to us whenever we call on him?
speaker: Narrator

text: What other great nation is there that has statutes and ordinances as righteous as this entire law that I am presenting to you today?
speaker: Narrator

text: But guard yourselves and guard your whole being diligently, so that you do not forget the things that your eyes have seen and so that those things do not disappear from your heart all the rest of the days of your life. Make them known to your children and to your children’s children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell about the day that you stood before the Lord your God at Horeb when the Lord said to me, “Bring the people near to me and I will make sure that they hear my words, so that they may learn to fear me all the days that they are living in the land, and so that they may teach their children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So you drew near and you stood under the mountain while the mountain was burning with fire up to the very heavens. There was darkness, a thick cloud, and gloom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord your God spoke to you from the middle of the fire. You heard the sound of the words, but you did not see a form. You only heard the sound.
speaker: Narrator

text: He declared to you his covenant that he commanded you to carry out, namely, the Ten Commandments. Then he wrote them on two tablets of stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord commanded me to teach you the statutes and ordinances for you to carry out in the land that you are entering in order to occupy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So guard your hearts very carefully, because you did not see any form on the day that the Lord your God spoke to you at Horeb from the middle of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this so that you do not act corruptly and make for yourselves an idol of any form. Do not make an image of a male or female,
speaker: Narrator

text: an image of any animal that walks on the earth, an image of any bird that flies in the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text: an image of anything that creeps on the ground, or an image of any fish that swims in the water below the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beware so that you do not lift up your eyes to the heavens and see the sun and the moon and the stars, all the vast army of the heavens, and you are lured away, and you bow down to them and worship them—things that the Lord your God has allotted to all the nations under all the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you are the ones that the Lord has chosen and has brought out of the iron furnace of Egypt, to be a nation that is his possession, as is the case today.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord was angry with me because of your words, and he swore that I would not cross the Jordan and would not come into the good land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will die in this land without crossing over the Jordan, but you will cross over and take possession of this good land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be on guard so that you do not forget the covenant that the Lord your God made with you and so that you do not make an idol for yourselves in the form of anything that the Lord your God prohibited.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is a consuming fire, a jealous God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when you become the father of children, and you have grandchildren, and you have grown old in the land, if you then act corruptly by making an idol of any form, and you do evil in the eyes of the Lord your God, provoking him to anger,
speaker: Narrator

text: I today call the heavens and the earth as witnesses against you, that you will most certainly perish quickly from the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess. You will not live many days in it, because you will most certainly be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will scatter you among the peoples, and you will be left as a people that are few in number among the nations where the Lord your God will force you to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you will worship gods, the work of human hands, made of wood and stone—things that do not see or hear or eat or smell.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from there you will seek the Lord your God, and you will find him when you search for him with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you experience misery and all these things have happened to you in future days, then you will return to the Lord your God, and you will be obedient to his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is a compassionate God. He will not leave you or destroy you or forget the covenant that he promised to your fathers with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: So ask now about the former days, long before your time, beginning from the day when God created man on the earth. Search from one end of the heavens to the other. Has there ever been anything like this great event, or has anything like it ever been heard?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has a people ever heard the voice of God speaking from the middle of fire as you heard and yet continued to live?
speaker: Narrator

text: Or has a god ever tried to go and take for himself a nation from inside another nation by tests, signs, and warnings, or by war, by a strong hand and an outstretched arm, and by great awe-inspiring acts like all those that the Lord your God did for you in Egypt in front of your very eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves were shown this so that you could know that the Lord—he is God! There is none except him alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He let you hear his voice from the heavens to discipline you, and on earth he let you see his great fire, and you heard his words from the middle of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, because he loved your fathers and chose their descendants after them, he brought you out of Egypt by the great power of his Presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: driving out from your presence nations greater and stronger than you are, to bring you in, to give you their land as an inheritance, as it is this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore know this today and again take it to heart that the Lord is God in the heavens above and on the earth below. There is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep his statutes and his commandments that I am commanding you today, so that it may go well for you and for your children after you, and so that you may live long on the land that the Lord your God is giving you for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses set aside three cities in the region east of the Jordan, the place where the sun rises,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that someone who killed a man could flee to them, that is, someone who killed his neighbor unintentionally and who did not previously hate him—he could flee to one of these cities and remain alive:
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezer in the wilderness in the tableland belonging to the Reubenites, Ramoth in Gilead belonging to the Gadites, and Golan in Bashan belonging to the Manassites.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the Law that Moses set before the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the testimonies and statutes and ordinances that Moses spoke to the people of Israel when they went out of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: in the region east of the Jordan opposite Beth Peor in the land of Sihon king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, whom Moses and the children of Israel struck down when they came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took possession of his land as well as the land of Og king of Bashan, the two kings of the Amorites who were in the region east of the Jordan, where the sun rises.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took possession from Aroer, which is on the edge of the Arnon Canyon, all the way to Mount Siyon, that is, Mount Hermon,
speaker: Narrator

text: including all of the Arabah on the east side of the Jordan, up to the Sea of the Arabah below the slopes of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called together all Israel and said this to them: Listen, Israel, to the statutes and ordinances that I am speaking in your hearing today so that you learn them and are conscientious about carrying them out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God made a covenant with us at Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did not make this covenant with our fathers, but with us, with those who are here today, all of us who are living today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Face-to-face the Lord spoke with you at the mountain from the middle of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At that time I was standing between the Lord and you to relate to you the word of the Lord, because you were afraid of the fire and you did not go up on the mountain.
Then the Lord said:
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from the land of Egypt, where you were slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall have no other gods beside me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not make any carved image for yourself or a likeness of anything in heaven above, on the earth below, or in the waters under the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bow down to them or be subservient to them, for I the Lord your God am a jealous God. I follow up on the guilt of the fathers with their children, their grandchildren, and their great-grandchildren if they also hate me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I show mercy to thousands who love me and keep my commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not misuse the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not permit anyone who misuses his name to escape unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Observe the Sabbath day by setting it apart as holy, just as the Lord your God commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you are to serve and perform all of your regular work,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh day is a sabbath rest to the Lord your God. You are not to do any regular work, you or your son or your daughter or your male servant or your female servant or your ox or your donkey or any of your livestock or the alien who resides inside your gates, in order that your male servant and your female servant may rest like you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were slaves in the land of Egypt and that the Lord your God brought you out from there with a strong hand and an outstretched arm. Therefore the Lord your God commanded you to keep the day of rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Honor your father and your mother, just as the Lord your God commanded you, so that you may prolong your days and so that it may go well for you on the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not commit murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not give lying testimony against your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife. And you shall not desire your neighbor’s house or his field, his male servant or his female servant, his ox or his donkey, or anything that belongs to your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the words the Lord spoke to your whole assembly at the mountain from the middle of the fire, the thick cloud, and the gloom, with a loud voice, and he did not add anything. He wrote them on two tablets of stone and gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you heard the voice from the middle of the darkness while the mountain was burning with fire, you approached me—all the heads of your tribes and your elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you said, “See how the Lord our God has shown us his glory and his greatness, and we have heard his voice from the middle of the fire. Today we have seen that a man can live even though God has spoken to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, why should we die, because this great fire will consume us? If we continue to hear the voice of the Lord our God any longer, we will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: For who of all flesh has ever heard the voice of the living God speaking from the middle of fire as we have and has lived?
speaker: Narrator

text: You go near and listen to everything that the Lord our God says, and then you speak to us everything that the Lord our God speaks to you, and we will hear and do it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord heard what you said when you spoke to me. So the Lord said to me, “I heard what these people said when they spoke to you. Everything that they spoke to you is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: If only this would be in their hearts—to fear me and to keep all my commandments always, so that it might go well for them and for their children continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and say to them, ‘Go back to your tents.’
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, stand here with me and I will speak to you all the commands and the statutes and the ordinances that you are to teach them and that they are to do in the land that I am giving them as a possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell them: ‘Be conscientious about doing just as the Lord your God commanded you. Do not turn aside to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Walk in every way the Lord your God has commanded you, so that you may live and it may be good for you and you may live long in the land that you will possess.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses spoke as follows:
Now this is the body of commands, and these are the statutes and the ordinances that the Lord your God commanded me to teach you, so you may carry them out in the land to which you are crossing over to receive as a possession,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that you may fear the Lord your God by keeping all his statutes and his commandments, which I am commanding to you, as well as to your children and grandchildren, all the days of your life, and so that your days may be long.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, O Israel, and be conscientious about doing those things, so it may go well for you and so you may increase greatly in a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your fathers, promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, O Israel! The Lord is our God. The Lord is one!
speaker: Narrator

text: Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your might.
speaker: Narrator

text: These words that I am commanding you today are to be on your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them diligently to your children, and speak about them when you sit in your house and when you walk on the road, when you lie down and when you get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tie them as a sign on your wrists, and they will serve as symbols on your forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them on the doorposts of your houses and on your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God brings you to the land about which he swore to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, that he would give it to you, he will bring you to great and good cities that you did not build,
speaker: Narrator

text: to houses full of all kinds of good things that you did not fill, to wells that you did not dig, and to vineyards and olives that you did not plant. Then, when you eat and are full,
speaker: Narrator

text: watch yourself, so that you do not forget the Lord, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, where you were slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear the Lord your God, serve him, and swear by his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not go after other gods from among the gods of the peoples around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do, the Lord your God will be a jealous God in your midst, and the anger of the Lord your God will burn against you, and he will destroy you from the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not put the Lord your God to the test the way you tested him at Massah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be very conscientious about keeping the commandments of the Lord your God and his testimonies and his statutes, which he commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do what is right and good in the eyes of the Lord, so that it may go well for you and you may go and take possession of the good land that the Lord promised to your fathers with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: driving out all your enemies from your presence, as the Lord promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your son asks you in the future, “What are these testimonies and statutes and ordinances that the Lord our God has commanded for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: then you are to say to your son, “We were slaves of Pharaoh in Egypt, but the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right before our eyes the Lord gave great, devastating signs and wonders in Egypt against Pharaoh and against his whole household.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought us out of there to bring us in and give us the land that he promised to our fathers with an oath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord commanded us to carry out all of these statutes, to fear the Lord our God for our own lasting good, to keep us alive, even as we are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Righteousness will be ours when we are conscientious about carrying out this entire set of commands in the presence of the Lord our God as he commanded us.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God brings you into the land that you are entering to take as a possession, and when he clears away many nations before you (the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, seven nations more numerous and stronger than you),
speaker: Narrator

text: and when the Lord your God has given them over to you and he has struck them down, you are to devote them to destruction. Do not make a treaty with them, and do not show mercy to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not form marriage alliances with them. Do not give your daughters to their sons, and do not take their daughters for your sons,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they will turn your sons away from following me, and they will serve other gods. The anger of the Lord will burn against you, and then he will destroy you quickly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, this is the way you must deal with them: Break down their altars. Smash their sacred memorial stones. Cut down their Asherah poles. Burn their idols with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are a people that is holy to the Lord your God, because the Lord your God has chosen you to belong to him as a people that is his treasured possession, chosen from all the peoples that are on the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord became attached to you by love and has chosen you, not because you were more numerous than all the peoples. Actually you were the fewest of all the peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: But because of the Lord’s love for you and because he was keeping the oath that he swore to your fathers, that is why the Lord brought you out by a strong hand and redeemed you from the house of slavery, from the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did this so that you would know that the Lord your God, yes, he is God, the faithful God who maintains both his covenant and his mercy for those who love him and keep his commandments, to a thousand generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he also repays the ones who hate him to their face by destroying them. He will not delay repaying anyone who hates him. To his face he will fully repay him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to be careful to keep the set of commandments and the statutes and the ordinances that I am commanding you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you obey these ordinances and are careful to keep them, the Lord your God will keep for your benefit the covenant and the mercy that he promised to your fathers with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will love you and bless you and multiply you. He will bless the fruit from your womb and the fruit from your soil, your grain and your new wine and your fresh olive oil, the offspring of your cattle and the young of your flock upon the land that he swore to your fathers that he would give you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed beyond all the peoples. There will not be an infertile male or infertile female among you or among your livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will remove from you all sickness, and he will not place on you all of the diseases of Egypt, the calamities that you experienced. Instead he will put them on all those who hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will consume all the peoples that the Lord your God is giving to you. Your eye is not to look with compassion on them. You are not to serve their gods, because that would be a snare to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you say in your heart, “These nations are more numerous than we are. How are we able to take possession of their land?”
speaker: Narrator

text: do not be afraid of them. Be sure to remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and to all the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: The great test which your eyes saw and the signs and the wonders and the strong hand and the outstretched arm by which the Lord your God brought you out—that is what the Lord your God will do to all the peoples that you fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will also send the hornet against them until those who are left and are hiding from you have been destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be overwhelmed before them, because the Lord your God is right among you, a great and awe-inspiring God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God, the God before you, will clear away the nations little by little. You will not succeed in finishing them off too quickly, so that the wild animals do not become too numerous for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God will give them over to you, and he will throw these peoples into complete confusion until they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give their kings into your hands, and he will cause their names to die out under the heavens, because none of them will be able to hold their ground against you until you have destroyed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Burn the images of their gods with fire, and do not covet the silver and gold on them or take it for yourself, so that you are not snared by it, because it is an abomination to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bring a detestable thing to your house and in that way become devoted to destruction just like it. Detest it and regard it as an utterly disgusting thing, because it is devoted to destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be conscientious about carrying out the entire body of commands that I am giving you today so that you may thrive and increase and you may go in and possess the land that the Lord promised by oath to give to your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember the whole journey on which the Lord your God led you these forty years in the wilderness, in order to humble you and to test you, in order to know what was in your heart, whether or not you would keep his commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he humbled you and allowed you to be hungry. Then he fed you manna, which neither you nor your fathers had known before, in order to teach you that man does not live by bread alone, but man lives by every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The clothes you wore did not wear out, and your feet did not swell these forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: So know in your heart that just as a man disciplines his son, so the Lord your God disciplines you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you are to keep the commandments of the Lord your God by walking in his ways and by revering him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is bringing you into a good land, a land of gullies filled with water, a land with springs and groundwater that flows out into the valleys and down the mountains,
speaker: Narrator

text: a land with wheat and barley and vines and fig trees and pomegranates, a land of olive trees for oil, and honey,
speaker: Narrator

text: a land where you can eat bread and not be poor, where you will not lack anything, a land whose rocks are iron and from whose mountains you can mine copper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will eat, and you will be filled, and you will praise the Lord your God for the good land that he has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be very careful so that you do not forget the Lord your God by not keeping his commandments and ordinances and his statutes that I am commanding you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you eat and are satisfied, and you build nice houses and move into them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and your herds and your flocks multiply, and your silver and gold increase, and everything that you have prospers,
speaker: Narrator

text: watch out so that your heart does not become arrogant and forget the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, where you were slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not forget the Lord, who led you in the great and terrifying wilderness, where there were venomous snakes and scorpions, where the thirsty ground had no water, but the Lord made water come out of a flint rock for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not forget the Lord, who in the wilderness fed you manna, which your fathers had not known before, to humble you and to test you so that it would be good for you later on.
speaker: Narrator

text: You might say in your heart, “My ability and the power of my hand have earned this wealth for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But then you are to remember that the Lord your God is the one who gives you the ability to produce wealth, to confirm his covenant that he promised to your fathers with an oath, as he does to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you ever do forget the Lord your God and you follow other gods, and if you serve them and bow down to them, I testify against you today that you will certainly perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just like the nations that the Lord is about to destroy in front of you, you also will perish, because you would not listen to the voice of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, Israel, today you are about to cross the Jordan to go in and to take possession of nations larger and stronger than you, nations with large cities that have fortified walls reaching up to the skies,
speaker: Narrator

text: with people strong and tall, the Anakites, whom you know and about whom you have heard it said: “Who can stand up against the descendants of Anak?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So know today that the Lord your God himself is crossing over in front of you. Like a consuming fire he will destroy them, and he will subdue them before you. You will take possession of their land and destroy them quickly, just as the Lord promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God has driven them out before you, do not say in your heart, “Because of my righteousness the Lord brought me in to take possession of this land,” when actually it is because of the wickedness of these nations that the Lord is handing over their land to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not entering to take possession of their land because of your righteousness or the uprightness of your heart, but because of the wickedness of these nations. The Lord your God is handing over their land to you, in order to confirm the promise that the Lord swore to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know, then, that it is not because of your righteousness that the Lord your God is giving you this good land to possess, because a stiff-necked people is what you are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember and do not forget how you made the Lord your God angry in the wilderness. From the day that you went out of the land of Egypt until your arrival at this place, you have been rebels against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even at Horeb you made the Lord angry. Yes, the Lord was angry enough at you to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I went up the mountain to receive the tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant that the Lord made with you, I stayed on the mountain forty days and forty nights. I did not eat bread and I did not drink water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord gave me the two tablets of stone written with the finger of God, and on them were all the words that the Lord had spoken with you from the middle of the fire on the mountain, on the day of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of the forty days and forty nights, the Lord gave me the two tablets of stone, the tablets of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “Get moving and go down quickly from here because your people, whom you led out of Egypt, have acted corruptly. They have turned away quickly from the way that I commanded them. They have made for themselves a thing of molten metal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to me, “I have seen these people, and what a stiff-necked people they are!
speaker: Narrator

text: Leave me alone, and I will destroy them. I will blot out their name from under the heavens, and I will make you into a nation stronger and more numerous than they.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I turned and went down the mountain with the two tablets of the covenant in my two hands, while the mountain was burning with fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw how you were sinning against the Lord your God by making for yourselves a calf from molten metal and by quickly turning aside from the way that the Lord your God had commanded you to go.
speaker: Narrator

text: I grabbed the two tablets and I threw them from my two hands and I shattered them right before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I lay facedown before the Lord forty days and forty nights like the first time. I did not eat bread and I did not drink water, because of all the sin that you committed by doing evil in the eyes of the Lord and making him angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was afraid of the heated anger of the Lord, who was angry enough at you to destroy you, but the Lord listened to me again at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was even angry enough with Aaron to destroy him. So I prayed also for Aaron at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I took that wicked thing that you had made, the calf. I burned it with fire and crushed it by grinding it until it was as fine as dust. Then I threw its dust into the gully that goes down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again and again, at Taberah and at Massah and at Kibroth Hatta’avah, you made the Lord angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, when the Lord sent you from Kadesh Barnea, and he said, “Go up and take possession of the land that I have given to you,” you rebelled against the command of the Lord your God. You did not put your faith in him, and you did not obey him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have been rebels against the Lord ever since I have known you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I lay facedown before the Lord for forty days and forty nights. I lay facedown because the Lord said he would destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I prayed to the Lord and said, “Lord God, do not destroy your people, your inheritance that you have redeemed by your greatness, whom you brought out of Egypt with a strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Do not look at the stubbornness of these people and at their wickedness and their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise the land out of which you brought us will say, ‘This happened because the Lord did not have the power to bring them to the land that he had promised to them, or this happened because he hated them and brought them out to kill them in the wilderness.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But they are your people and your possession, whom you brought out by your great power and by your outstretched arm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord said to me, “Cut out two tablets of stone like the first ones, and come up to me on the mountain, and make an ark out of wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will write on the tablets the same words that were on the first ones that you shattered, and you are to put them in the ark.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I made an ark of acacia wood and I cut out two tablets of stone like the first ones, and I went up the mountain with the two tablets in my hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wrote on the tablets the same writing as on the first tablets, the Ten Commandments that the Lord had spoken to you on the mountain from the middle of the fire, on the day of the assembly. Then the Lord gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I turned and came back down the mountain, and I put the tablets in the ark that I had made. There they are kept, as the Lord commanded me to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel traveled from Be’eroth Bene Ja’akan to Moserah. Aaron died there, and he was buried there, and Eleazar his son served as priest in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they traveled to Gudgodah, and from Gudgodah to Jotbathah, a land of gullies filled with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, to stand before the Lord and to serve him, and to pronounce a blessing in his name, as they do to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why Levi did not have an allotment of land and an inheritance with his brothers. The Lord himself is their inheritance, as the Lord your God promised him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had stayed on the mountain for forty days and forty nights like the first time, and the Lord listened to me again on this second occasion. The Lord agreed not to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to me, “Set out and continue the journey at the head of the people, and they will enter and take possession of the land that I promised to give them with an oath to their fathers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, Israel, what is the Lord your God asking of you but to fear the Lord your God, to walk in all his ways, and to love him and to serve the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul,
speaker: Narrator

text: to keep the commandments of the Lord and his statutes that I am commanding you today for your own good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, the heavens and the heaven of heavens, the earth and everything that is on it—these belong to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, the Lord attached himself to your fathers, loved them, and he chose their descendants after them (that’s you!) from all peoples, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: So cut away the tough shell of your sinful nature, and do not be stubborn any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God is God of Gods and Lord of Lords, the great God, the mighty one and the awesome one, who does not show favoritism and does not take a bribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carries out justice for the fatherless and widows. He loves the alien who dwells among you and gives him food and clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to love the alien, because you were aliens in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear the Lord your God, serve him, cling to him, and take your oaths in his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is your glory. He is your God, who performed for you these great and awesome things that your own eyes have seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your fathers went down to Egypt, they numbered seventy people, but now the Lord your God has made you as numerous as the stars of the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Love the Lord your God and always carry out his requirements, his statutes, his ordinances, and his commandments.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
his signs and his deeds that he performed in Egypt
    against Pharaoh king of Egypt and against all his land;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: what he did for you in the wilderness until you came to this place;
speaker: Narrator

text:
what he did to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab son of Reuben;
how the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them
with their households, their tents,
and every living thing that was at their feet,
in the middle of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Know today it is your own eyes that have seen every deed that the Lord your God performed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, keep the whole set of commands that I am giving you today so that you may have the strength to enter and take possession of the land that you are about to cross into and possess,
speaker: Narrator

text: and so that you may live for a long time on the land that the Lord your God swore to give to your fathers and to their descendants, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land that you are about to enter and possess is not like that land of Egypt that you left, where you were accustomed to sow your seed and water it by hand like a vegetable garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the land you are entering to possess is a land of mountains and valleys. It drinks water provided by rain from the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a land that the Lord your God takes care of. The eyes of the Lord your God are continually on it, from the start to the end of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you faithfully listen to my commandments that I am giving you today, to love the Lord your God and to serve him with all your heart and with all your soul,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will provide rain for your land in season, early fall rain and late spring rain, and you will gather your grain and your new wine and your fresh oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will provide grass in your field for your livestock, and you will eat and be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful, or your heart will be deceived and you will turn away and serve other gods and bow down to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anger of the Lord will burn against you, and he will close up the heavens. There will be no rain, the ground will not produce crops, and you will perish quickly from the good land that the Lord is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put these words of mine in your hearts and in your soul, and tie them on your wrists as signs and as symbols on your forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them to your children by talking about them when you sit in your house and when you travel on the road, when you lie down and when you get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them on the doorframes of your houses and on your gates,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that your days and the days of your children may be many on the land that the Lord promised to your fathers with an oath, as many as the days that the heavens remain over the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you carefully keep the whole set of commandments that I am giving you, loving the Lord your God, walking in all his ways, and clinging to him,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will drive out all these nations before you, and you will take possession of nations larger and stronger than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every place where the sole of your foot walks will be yours. From the Wilderness to Lebanon, from the River—the River Euphrates—to the Mediterranean Sea, all of it will be your territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will be able to stand up to you. The Lord your God will put the fear and dread of you over the whole land on which you walk, just as he promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see, I am placing before you today a blessing and a curse:
speaker: Narrator

text: the blessing, if you listen to the commandments of the Lord your God that I am giving you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: or the curse, if you do not listen to the commandments of the Lord your God and you turn away from the path that I am commanding you today by walking after other gods whom you did not know.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God brings you into the land you are about to enter and possess, you are to pronounce the blessing on Mount Gerizim and the curse on Mount Ebal.
speaker: Narrator

text: As you know, they are on the other side of the Jordan, beyond the west road, toward the setting sun, in the land of the Canaanites that live in the Arabah, opposite Gilgal, by the oaks of Moreh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are about to cross over the Jordan to go in and take the land that the Lord your God is giving you. You will take it and live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be careful to carry out all the statutes and the ordinances that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the statutes and the ordinances that you are to be conscientious about keeping in the land that the Lord, the God of your fathers, has given to you to possess all the days that you live in the land:
speaker: Narrator

text: Completely destroy all the places where the nations that you are driving out serve their gods, whether on the high mountains or on the hills or under every beautiful green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tear down their altars! Smash their sacred memorial stones! Burn their Asherah poles with fire, and cut down the carved images of their gods! In this way you will destroy their names from those places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not serve the Lord your God in the way that they worship,
speaker: Narrator

text: but seek out and go to the site that the Lord your God will choose from within all your tribes to place his name and his dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you are to bring your burnt offerings and your sacrifices, your tithes and the elevated offerings from your hands, your offerings to fulfill a vow, your voluntary offerings, and the firstborn of your herd and your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat there in the presence of the Lord your God, and rejoice in everything you do, you and your household, because the Lord your God has blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not in any way do what we are doing here today, that is, each person doing whatever is right in his own eyes,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you have not yet come to your place of rest, the inheritance that the Lord your God is giving to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will cross over the Jordan and settle in the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, and he will give you rest from all your enemies all around you, so that you will live in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go to the place that the Lord your God chooses as the place to establish his name. There you are to bring everything that I am commanding you: your burnt offerings and your sacrifices, your tithes, the offerings from your hands, and all the best voluntary offerings that you vow to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will rejoice before the Lord your God, you and your sons and your daughters, and your male servants and your female servants, and the Levites who live within the gates of your cities, because they do not have an allotted inheritance among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you do not offer up your burnt offering in just any place that you see fit,
speaker: Narrator

text: but only in the place that the Lord will choose in one of your tribes. That is where you are to offer up your burnt offerings and where you are to do everything that I am commanding you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in any town you may butcher and eat meat to your heart’s content, as the Lord your God has blessed you. The unclean and the clean person alike may eat it as they would a gazelle or a deer,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you must never eat the blood. Pour it on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to eat the tithe from your grain, your new wine, or your fresh oil in your towns. The same applies to the firstborn of your herd and your flock, or anything you vow, or your voluntary offerings, or your special elevated offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat those things before the Lord your God in the place that the Lord your God will choose—you and your sons and your daughters, your male servants and your female servants, and the Levites within your cities. Rejoice before the Lord your God in everything that you are doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you do not neglect the Levites as long as you live on your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God expands your territory as he promised you, and you say, “I would like to eat meat,” because you are hungry for meat, then you may eat it to your heart’s content.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the place that the Lord your God will choose to establish his name is too far away for you, then you may slaughter animals from your herd and flock which the Lord has given you, just as I commanded you, and you may eat within your cities as you desire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, just as gazelle and deer are eaten, you may eat it. The unclean and the clean person alike may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only be very sure not to eat the blood, because the blood is the life, and you must not eat the life together with the flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat it. Pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat it, so that it may go well for you and for your children after you when you do what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for the holy things that you have and your voluntary offerings, gather them up and take them to the place that the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Offer your burnt offerings, both the flesh and the blood, on the altar of the Lord your God. The blood of the sacrifice is to be poured out on the altar of the Lord your God, but the meat you may eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you obey all these words that I am commanding you so that it may go well for you and for your children after you in the distant future when you do what is good and right in the eyes of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God cuts off the nations where you are going and drives them out before you, and when you take possession of their land and settle in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: be careful that you are not snared after they have been destroyed before you. Do not inquire about their gods and ask, “How did these people serve their gods? I also want to do the same thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not serve the Lord your God in the way that they worship, because they do for their gods every detestable thing that the Lord hates. They even burn their sons and daughters in fire for their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to do everything that I am commanding you. Do not add to it, and do not subtract from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a prophet or an interpreter of dreams arises among you, and he predicts a sign or wonder for you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sign or wonder that he promised you comes true, and he says, “Let’s go after other gods that you do not know, and let’s serve them,”
speaker: Narrator

text: do not listen to the words of that prophet or that interpreter of dreams, because the Lord your God is testing you to see whether you really love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow the Lord your God, fear him, keep his commandments, listen to his voice, serve him, and cling to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: That prophet or that interpreter of dreams is to be put to death because he advised you to turn against the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt and redeemed you from the house of slavery, in order to draw you away from the path on which the Lord your God commanded you to walk. Purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your full brother or your mother’s son, your son or your daughter, the wife you embrace, or your closest friend tempts you by saying secretly, “Let’s go and serve other gods,”—gods that neither you nor your fathers have known,
speaker: Narrator

text: from among the gods of the peoples around you, either near or far from you, anywhere from one end of the land to the other—
speaker: Narrator

text: do not be influenced by him and do not listen to him. Your eye is not to look on him with compassion. Do not spare him and do not pardon him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but kill him. Your hand is to be the first one on him when putting him to death, and afterward the hands of all the other people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stone him to death, because he tried to pull you away from the Lord your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, where you were slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of Israel will hear and fear, and such an evil thing as this will not be done among you again.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you hear in one of your cities, which the Lord your God is giving you so that you can live in them,
speaker: Narrator

text: men of worthless character have gone out from among you and have pulled the inhabitants of their city away from the Lord, saying, “Let’s go and serve other gods,” gods whom you have not known,
speaker: Narrator

text: then investigate, search out the truth, and inquire diligently. If it becomes established truth that this abomination has been done among you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to strike down the inhabitants of that city with the blade of the sword. Devote it and everything in it to complete destruction by the blade of the sword, including its cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather all its plunder at the center of its town square. Then burn the city and all its plunder as a whole burnt offering to the Lord your God. It is to be a permanent mound of ruins, never to be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let nothing that has been devoted to destruction stick to your hands, so that the Lord will turn away from his anger and show you compassion. In his compassion he will increase your population, as he swore to your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you obey the voice of the Lord your God by keeping all of his commandments that I am commanding you today, by doing what is right in the eyes of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the children of the Lord your God.
Do not cut yourselves or make a bald spot on your forehead for a dead person,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you are set apart as holy people for the Lord your God, and the Lord your God has chosen you out of all the people that are on the face of the earth, to be his people that are his treasured possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat any detestable thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the animals that you may eat: cattle, sheep, and goats;
speaker: Narrator

text: deer, gazelle, roebuck, wild goat, ibex, antelope, and mountain sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every animal that has divided hoofs with splits in the middle and that rechews its food among the animals—you may eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But these you are not to eat from among those that either rechew their food or have divided hoofs with splits in the middle: the camel, the hare, and the rock badger, because even though they rechew their food, their hoofs are not divided. They are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pig, because it has divided hoofs but does not rechew its food, is unclean for you. You are not to eat their flesh and you are not to touch their carcasses.
speaker: Narrator

text: These you may eat of all the creatures that live in the water: Any that have fins and scales you may eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any that do not have fins and scales you are not to eat. They are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any clean bird you may eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you are not to eat the following: the eagle, the black vulture, and the bearded vulture,
speaker: Narrator

text: the red kite, the black kite, and falcons of every kind,
speaker: Narrator

text: ravens and crows of every kind,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eagle owl, the short-eared owl, the long-eared owl, all species of hawks,
speaker: Narrator

text: the tawny owl, the fisher owl, the screech owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: the white owl, and the scops owl, the osprey,
speaker: Narrator

text: the stork and herons of every kind, the hoopoe, and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any swarming insect that flies is unclean for you. None of them are to be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any clean winged creature you may eat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not eat the carcass of any animal that is found dead. You may give it to the alien who resides in your town, and he may eat it or sell it to a foreigner, but you are a people who are set apart as holy for the Lord your God.
Do not boil a baby goat in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give a tenth of all the yield from your seed that comes out of the field every year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat the tithe in the presence of the Lord your God in the place that he will choose to establish his name—the tenth of your grain, your new wine, and your fresh oil, as well as the firstborn of your herd and flock, so that you may learn to fear the Lord your God always.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God blesses you, if the distance of your journey is so long that you cannot carry the tithe with you, because the place that the Lord your God will choose to establish his name is far away from you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you may exchange the tithe for silver and take the silver in your hand and travel to the place that the Lord your God will choose for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: There exchange the silver for anything that you desire—animals from the herd or the flock, or wine or beer, or anything that you may want. Then eat it there before the Lord your God and rejoice, both you and your household.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not neglect the Levites who reside within the gates of your cities, because they do not have an allotted inheritance among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of every third year, bring out the entire tithe of your produce from that year and store it in your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Levites may come, because they do not have an allotted inheritance among you, and also the aliens and the fatherless and the widows within your towns, and they may eat and be satisfied, so that the Lord your God may bless you in all the work that your hands perform.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of seven years grant a release.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how the release is to be done: Every creditor is to release what he has loaned to his neighbor. He must not exact it from his neighbor or from his brother Israelite, because the Lord’s release has been proclaimed.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may exact it from a foreigner, but your hand is to release whatever your brother Israelite owes you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, there should be no poor people among you, because the Lord will greatly bless you in the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance for you to possess,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you obey the voice of the Lord your God by carefully carrying out all of this command that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God will bless you, just as he has promised you, and you will lend to many nations, but you will not borrow; you will rule over many nations, but they will not rule over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if there is a poor person among you, any one of your fellow Israelites within the gates of your towns in the land that the Lord your God is giving you, do not harden your heart and shut your hand against your poor brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, open up your hand to him and freely lend him enough of whatever he needs for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful that you do not harbor this wicked thought: Year seven, the year of release, is near! So as a result you have a harsh attitude toward your poor brother and do not give him anything. Then he will cry out to the Lord against you, and you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give freely to him, and do not feel resentful about giving to him, because on account of your giving, the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and whatever you put your hand to.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since there will never cease to be poor people in the land, I command you, open up your hand to your brother in your land, to the afflicted and the poor among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your brother, that is, a Hebrew man or woman, sells himself to you, he is to serve you for six years. But in the seventh year you are to set him free.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you set him free, do not send him out empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Provide for him generously from your flock and from your threshing floor and from your winepress. Give to him from the blessings that the Lord your God has given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should remember that you yourself were a slave in the land of Egypt, but the Lord your God redeemed you. Therefore I am commanding this procedure to you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he might say to you, “I don’t want to leave you,” because he loves you and your household, and he is well off with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case you are to take an awl and bore through his ear into the door, and he will be a slave to you permanently. Do the same in the case of your female slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you do set a servant free, it should not seem like a hardship to you, because for six years he has earned for you double the income that a hired worker would. The Lord your God will bless you in everything that you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set apart for the Lord your God every firstborn male from your herd and your flock. Do not work the firstborn of your oxen, and do not shear the firstborn of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You and your household are to eat the firstborn in the presence of the Lord each year, in the place that the Lord will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it has a defect (if it is lame or blind, or if it has any other serious defect), you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat it within the gates of your towns. The unclean and the clean person alike may eat it, as you would a gazelle or a deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not eat its blood. You are to pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator
