text: Observe the month of Abib and keep the Passover for the Lord your God, because it was in the month of Abib that the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt at night.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a Passover sacrifice to the Lord your God, slaughter an animal from the flock or herd at the place where the Lord will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat leavened bread with it. For seven days eat unleavened bread, the bread of affliction, because you went out of the land of Egypt in a hurry. Do this so that you may remember the day that you went out from the land of Egypt for all the days of your life.
speaker: Narrator

text: No yeast or leaven is to be found among you for seven days, and none of the meat that you sacrifice on the evening of the first day is to be left until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not allowed to sacrifice the Passover inside the gates of any of the cities that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, it is at the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name that you are to sacrifice the Passover, in the evening at the setting of the sun, the time of day that you went out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cook it and eat it at the place that the Lord your God will choose. In the morning return to your tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you are to eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day there is to be a special convocation to the Lord your God. Do not do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Count off seven weeks. As the starting point of the seven weeks, mark the time that the sickle first strikes the standing grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then observe the Festival of Weeks for the Lord your God and give a voluntary offering of as much as you can afford, in keeping with how much the Lord has blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice before the Lord your God, you and your son and your daughter, your male servant and your female servant, the Levite who is within the gates of your city, and the alien and the fatherless and the widow who are among you. Do this in the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt, so you are to be careful to carry out these statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: After you have gathered in the produce from your threshing floor and your winepress, celebrate the Festival of Shelters for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rejoice in your festival, you and your son and your daughter, and your male servant and your female servant, and the alien and the orphan and the widow within your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days celebrate to the Lord your God in the place that the Lord will choose, because the Lord your God will bless you in all of your crops and in all the work of your hands, and you will most certainly be joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three times a year all of your males are to present themselves before the Lord your God at the place that he will choose: at the Festival of Unleavened Bread, at the Festival of Weeks, and at the Festival of Shelters. They are not to present themselves before the Lord empty-handed,
speaker: Narrator

text: but each person is to have in his hand a gift that is in keeping with the blessing that the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Appoint judges and officers for your tribes to serve at the gates of all the cities that the Lord your God is giving you. They are to judge the people with righteous judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not distort justice. Do not show partiality. Do not take a bribe, because a bribe blinds the eyes of wise people and twists the actions of righteous people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Justice! You are to pursue justice, so that you may live and possess the land that the Lord your God is giving you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not set up any kind of wooden Asherah pole beside the altar of the Lord your God that you have made for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not set up for yourself a sacred memorial stone, which is something that the Lord your God hates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not sacrifice to the Lord your God any ox or sheep that has any kind of defect or serious flaw, because that is something detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is found among you (within the gates of one of your cities that the Lord your God is giving you) a man or a woman who is doing something that is evil in the eyes of the Lord your God by transgressing his covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text: or a man or a woman who is going and serving other gods and bowing down to them or to the sun or to the moon or to any of the army of the heavens, something that I have not commanded,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are told about it and you listen and investigate diligently, and it is established that the charge is true and that this abomination has been committed in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you are to bring that man or that woman who has committed this evil out to your city gate, and you are to stone that person to death, whether man or woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person is to be put to death on the basis of the testimony of two or three witnesses. No one is to be put to death based on the testimony of one witness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hands of the witnesses are to be the first ones raised against him when putting him to death, and after that the hands of all the other people. In that way you are to purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a case is too difficult for you to make a decision, whether it involves a homicide, a lawsuit, or an assault, or any matters of controversy within the gates of your cities, then proceed by going up to the place that the Lord your God will choose.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the priests, who are from the tribe of Levi, and to the presiding judge at that time and lay out the case. They will declare the verdict to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to act according to the verdict that they will declare to you from the place that the Lord will choose, and you are to be careful to carry out everything that they instruct you to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Act according to the instructions they give you and according to the judgment that they speak to you. Do not turn to the right or to the left from the word that they declare to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any man who acts presumptuously by not listening to the priest, who presides and serves the Lord your God there, or by not listening to the judge, that man is condemned to die. In that way you will purge the evil from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people will hear and fear and not act presumptuously anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have entered the land that the Lord your God is giving you, and you have taken possession of it and settled in it, and you say, “I am determined to set a king over me, like all the nations that are around me,”
speaker: Narrator

text: you may set a king over yourself, one whom the Lord your God will choose. You may set over yourself a king who is from among your brother Israelites. You must not set a foreigner over you, one who is not your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king must not accumulate more and more horses for himself, and he must not send people back to Egypt in order to accumulate more horses, because the Lord has said to you, “You must not go back that way again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not accumulate more and more wives for himself, or his heart may go astray. He must not accumulate excessive silver and gold for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he sits on his royal throne, he is to have a copy of this law written for him on a scroll in the presence of the priests, who are from the tribe of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to remain with him, and he is to read it all the days of his life so that he learns to fear the Lord his God by being careful to carry out all the words of this law and these statutes,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that his heart does not grow haughty toward his brothers and turn away from this set of commands, either to the right or the left, so that the days of his royal reign in Israel, as well as that of his sons, may be many.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests, who are Levites, as well as the whole tribe of Levi, will not have any allotted inheritance with Israel. They will eat from the offerings made to the Lord by fire, which is their inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they will not have an inheritance among their brothers. The Lord is their inheritance, as he promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: This then will be the prescribed allotment for the priests from the people who offer sacrifices, whether an ox or a sheep: They are to give to the priests the shoulder, both cheeks, and the stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are also to give them the firstfruits from your grain, your new wine, your fresh oil, and the first fleece from your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God has chosen them from all of your tribes to stand in service in the name of the Lord—them and their sons for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a Levite comes from any of your towns throughout Israel where he resides, and whenever he follows his heart’s desire and comes to the place that the Lord will choose,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he serves in the name of the Lord your God, standing there before the Lord like all of his fellow Levites,
speaker: Narrator

text: then he may eat the same portion, regardless of any income he received from selling family property.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you, do not learn to practice anything like the abominations of those nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one be found among you who makes his son or his daughter pass through fire, or who uses divination, or who engages in fortune telling, or who observes omens, or who practices witchcraft,
speaker: Narrator

text: or who casts a magic spell, or who consults a ghost or a familiar spirit, or who inquires of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone doing these things is detestable to the Lord, and because of these abominations, the Lord your God is driving them out before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to be blameless with the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is true that those nations whose land you are taking listen to fortune tellers and diviners, but the Lord your God has not permitted you to do things like that.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among you, from your brother Israelites. Listen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is exactly what you asked from the Lord your God at Horeb on the day of the assembly. You said, “Do not let me hear the voice of the Lord my God anymore, and do not let me see this great fire again, or I will die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, “They have done well by saying what they said.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up a prophet for them from among their brothers, like you, and I will put my words in his mouth, and he will speak to them everything that I command him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who will not listen to my words that the prophet speaks in my name, I myself will call him to account.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any prophet who presumes to speak something in my name that I have not commanded him to speak or who speaks something in the name of other gods—that prophet shall die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What if you ask yourselves, “How can we know that the Lord has not spoken that word?”
speaker: Narrator

text: If a prophet speaks in the name of the Lord, and the thing does not come about and does not come true, the Lord has not spoken that word. The prophet has spoken it presumptuously. Do not be afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God has cut down the nations whose land the Lord your God is giving you, and you have taken possession of their land and settled in their cities and houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: set aside three cities within the land that the Lord your God is giving you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare roads for yourselves, and divide the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance into three parts, so that anyone who has killed a person will be able to flee to one of these cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now this is an example of a person who has killed someone who may flee there and live: someone who has struck down his friend unintentionally, without being hateful toward him beforehand.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, someone goes with his friend into the forest to cut down trees, and when his hand swings the ax to cut down the tree, the iron ax head slips off the wooden handle and strikes his friend, who then dies—that person may flee to one of these cities and live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, the avenger of blood might pursue the one who has killed someone, because the avenger is hot with anger. Then because of the long distance to the city of refuge, the avenger may overtake the man and strike him down fatally. His death would not be just, because he had not been hateful toward the other one beforehand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I am commanding you this: Set aside for yourselves three cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God expands your territory, as he swore to your fathers, and he gives you the entire land that he promised to give your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you carefully keep this whole set of commands that I am commanding you today, by loving the Lord your God and by walking in his ways always, then add for yourselves three more cities in addition to these three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then innocent blood will not be poured out within your land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, nor will you be guilty of bloodshed.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is a person who is hateful toward another, and he lies in ambush for him and springs up on him and strikes him so he dies, and the killer flees to one of the cities of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the elders of his home city are to send for him and take him from there. They are to hand him over to the avenger of blood, and he is to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eye is not to look with compassion on him. You are to purge the blood of the innocent person from Israel so that it may go well for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not move your neighbor’s boundary marker, which the first generation of occupants set up as a boundary for your inherited property in the land that the Lord your God is giving you to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: A single witness does not have legal standing to convict a person of any guilt or sin in connection with any wrongful action he may have committed. A case is to have standing only on the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a malicious witness rises up against a person to testify against him about a legal offense,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if the two people involved in the dispute stand before the Lord and before the priests and the judges who preside at that time,
speaker: Narrator

text: the judges are to investigate diligently. If the person is a dishonest witness because he has falsely accused his brother,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you are to do to him just as he had plotted to do to his brother. So you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the people will hear, and they will fear, and they will not do an evil thing like this among you again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eye is not to look with compassion. The principle is life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go out for battle against your enemies, and you see the horses and chariots of a people more numerous than you are, do not be afraid of them, because the Lord your God, who brought you up from the land of Egypt, is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are approaching the battle, the priest is to come forward and speak to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will say to them, “Listen, Israel, you are approaching the battle against your enemies. Do not let your heart become weak. Do not be afraid. Do not tremble. Do not dread them,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Lord your God is going with you to do battle for you against your enemies, to save you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The officers also are to speak to the people and say, “Whoever has built a new house but has not dedicated it, let him go and return to his house so that he does not die in the battle and another man dedicates it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever has planted a vineyard but has not yet removed it from sacred status, let him go and return to his house so that he does not die in the battle and another man is the first to eat from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever is pledged in marriage to a woman but has not consummated the marriage, let him go and return to his house so that he does not die in the battle and another man takes her in marriage.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the officers are to speak again to the people and say, “Whoever is afraid and fainthearted may go and return to his house, so that the hearts of his brother Israelites do not melt in cowardice like his heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officers finish speaking to the people, they are to appoint army commanders at the head of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you approach a city to fight against it, call out to it, asking for a peaceful surrender.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the city answers you, “Peace,” and it opens up its gates for you, then all the people found in it will become forced labor for you and they will serve you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it does not make peace with you, and it makes war against you, then lay siege against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will deliver it into your hands, and you will strike down all the males with the edge of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the women and the children, and the cattle and everything that is in the city—all its plunder—take as spoils of war for yourself. You may make use of the plunder of your enemies that the Lord your God gives you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this to all the cities that are very far away from you, which are not cities of the nations around here.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, from the cities of these people that the Lord your God is giving to you as your inheritance, do not keep alive anything that breathes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Devote them completely to destruction—the Hittites and the Amorites, the Canaanites and the Perizzites, the Hivites and the Jebusites—just as the Lord your God has commanded you,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they do not teach you to commit all of the abominations that they commit for their gods, with the result that you sin against the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you lay siege against a city for a long time, as you fight against it in order to capture it, do not destroy its trees by swinging axes against them, because you will be able to eat what the trees bear, so do not cut them down. For is a tree in the field something human that you should besiege it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Only trees that you know are not food-producing trees may be destroyed. You may cut them down to build siege works against the city that makes war against you, until it falls.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the land that the Lord your God is giving you to possess, if a person who has been killed is found lying in the open country and it is not known who struck him down,
speaker: Narrator

text: then your elders and your judges are to go out and measure the distance from the person who was killed to each of the surrounding towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the city that is closest to the person who was killed are to take a heifer that has not been worked and has not pulled with a yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of that city are to bring the heifer down to a gully that has a flowing stream and that has not been plowed and sown, and they are to break the neck of the heifer there in the gully.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priests, the descendants of Levi, are to come near, because the Lord your God has chosen them to serve and to bless you in the name of the Lord, and every dispute and every case of assault is to be decided according to their ruling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the elders of the city closest to the person who was killed are to wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken in the gully.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they are to testify by saying, “Our hands did not pour out this blood, and our eyes did not observe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Atone, Lord, for your people whom you have redeemed, and do not charge us with taking innocent life among your people Israel.” Then their bloodguilt will be atoned for.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way you will purge away from among you the guilt of shedding the blood of an innocent person by doing what is right in the eyes of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go out for battle against your enemies and the Lord your God gives them into your hands, if you take some of them as captives,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you see in that group of captives a beautiful woman, and you are attracted to her and would like to take her as your wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will bring her into your house. She is to shave her head and trim her nails.
speaker: Narrator

text: She also is to remove the clothing she wore when she was captured and to stay in your house and weep for her father and her mother for a month. After that you may come to her and become her husband and she will become your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then if you are no longer pleased with her, you are to let her go as she desires. You must not sell her for money. You are not to deal with her as a slave, because you have humiliated her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has two wives, and one is loved and one is not loved, and both the loved one and the unloved one have borne children for him, and the firstborn son belongs to the unloved wife,
speaker: Narrator

text: then on the day that he bequeaths what he owns to his sons, he cannot declare the son of the loved wife as his firstborn in preference to the son of the unloved wife, who is the true firstborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must acknowledge the son of the unloved wife as the firstborn by giving him a double portion of everything that is recognized as his. Because that son is the beginning of his father’s virility, the legal right of the firstborn belongs to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who does not obey the voice of his father and his mother, and they discipline him, but he will not listen to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then his father and his mother are to take hold of him and bring him out to the elders of his city and to the gate of his hometown.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will say to the elders of his city, “This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious. He does not obey us. He is a worthless glutton and a drunkard.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of his city are to stone him to death, and so you will purge the evil from among you, and all Israel will hear and fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is a man whose sin justly deserves a death sentence, and he is put to death, and you hang him on a tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: his dead body is not to remain on the tree overnight. You must bury him on the same day, because a person left hanging on a tree is cursed by God. You are not to defile your ground that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see an ox or a sheep that belongs to your brother Israelite going astray, do not ignore it. Return it to your brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your brother Israelite does not live nearby and you are not acquainted with him, bring it to your own house and keep it with you until your brother comes looking for it. Then return it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the same with his donkey, the same with his clothing, and the same with anything your brother has lost and you have found. You are not allowed to do nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see the donkey or ox that belongs to your brother Israelite and it has fallen on the road, do not ignore it. Help him lift it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: A woman must not wear the attire of a man, and a man is not to put on the clothing of a woman, because anyone doing these things is detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you happen to see a bird’s nest along the road, whether in a tree or on the ground, and it has young ones or eggs in it, and the mother is sitting over the young or on the eggs, do not take the mother along with the young birds.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may take the young birds for yourself, but be sure to set the mother free, so that it may go well for you and you may have a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you build a new house, you are to make a railing for your roof so you do not bring bloodguilt on your house if someone should fall from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not plant your vineyard with two kinds of seed. If you do, the whole yield becomes unusable—both the seed that you sow and the produce from the vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not plow with an ox and a donkey together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not wear fabric that is a mixture of wool and linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make tassels on the four corners of your clothing that you use to cover yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man marries a woman and goes to her, and afterward he hates her
speaker: Narrator

text: and accuses her with unfounded charges and defames her and says, “I married this woman, but when I approached her I found that she did not have evidence of virginity,”
speaker: Narrator

text: then the father and mother of the girl are to produce evidence of the girl’s virginity and bring it to the elders of the city at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The father of the girl shall say to the elders, “I gave my daughter to this man as a wife, and afterward he hated her,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he has accused her with unfounded charges by saying, ‘I have found that your daughter does not have evidence of virginity,’ but here is the evidence of my daughter’s virginity.” Then they are to spread out the bed covering in front of the elders of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of that city will take the man and discipline him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fine him a hundred pieces of silver and give them to the father of the girl because the man defamed a virgin of Israel. She shall continue to be his wife. He is not allowed to divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the accusation proves to be the truth because evidence of the girl’s virginity was not found,
speaker: Narrator

text: then they will bring the girl out to the entrance of her father’s house, and the men of her city will pelt her with stones until she dies, because she did a disgraceful thing in Israel by shaming the house of her father with her sexual immorality. In this way you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man is found lying down with a married woman, both of them are to die: the man lying with the woman, and also the woman. In that way you will purge the evil from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is a virgin pledged in marriage to a man, and another man comes upon her in the city and lies down with her,
speaker: Narrator

text: take both of them out to the gate of that city and pelt them with stones until they die—the girl, because she did not cry out for help in the city, and the man, because he violated the wife of another man. In that way you will purge the evil from your midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man comes upon a girl who has been pledged in marriage and they are out in the countryside, and he grabs her and lies down with her, then only the man that lay with her must die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not do anything to the girl. There is no sin worthy of death on her part, because this is like a case in which a man attacks another person and kills him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He came upon her in the open country, and the girl who was pledged in marriage cried out for help, but she had no one to rescue her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man finds a virgin who is not pledged in marriage and he grabs her and lies down with her and they are caught,
speaker: Narrator

text: the man lying down with her must give the father of the girl fifty pieces of silver, and she will become his wife. Because he violated her, he is not allowed to divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man must not marry the wife of his father; that is, he is not to remove the skirt that is reserved for his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: No man whose testicles are crushed or who has a severed penis is to come within the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: A child born of an incestuous relationship is not to come within the assembly of the Lord. Even in the tenth generation his descendant is not to come within the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: An Ammonite or a Moabite is not to come within the assembly. Even in the tenth generation their descendants may never come within the assembly of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they did not meet you with food and water on your journey after you came out of Egypt, and because they hired Balaam son of Beor from Pethor of Aram Naharaim to curse you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God was not willing to listen to Balaam, and the Lord your God turned the curse into a blessing for you, because the Lord your God loved you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not seek their peace and prosperity as long as you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not detest an Edomite, because he is your brother. Do not detest an Egyptian, because you were an alien in his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their children may come within the assembly of the Lord in the third generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you go out on a campaign against your enemies, you must guard yourselves against anything evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there is a man among you who is unclean because of an emission during the night, he must go outside the camp. He must not come inside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: Toward evening he is to bathe himself in water, and when the sun sets, he may re-enter the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to have a designated area outside the camp where you can go.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to your weapon, you must have a scraper with you so that when you squat out there, you can dig a hole with it and then proceed to cover up what comes out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the Lord your God is moving within your camp to save you and to defeat your enemies before you, your camp is to be holy. Do not let him see anything indecent among you so that he turns away from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not return a slave who escaped to you from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let him live with you, among your people, in the place he chooses within one of your cities that he thinks is good for him. Do not mistreat him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The daughters of Israel must not become female temple prostitutes, and neither are the sons of Israel to become male temple prostitutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bring the fee earned by a whore or the pay earned by a “dog” to the house of the Lord your God to fulfill any vow, because it is an abomination to the Lord. Yes, both of them are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not make your brother Israelite pay interest, whether interest of money or of food, or of anything that may be loaned out for interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may charge interest to a foreigner, but to your brother you are not to charge interest, so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything you do in the land that you are coming to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a vow to the Lord your God, do not delay fulfilling it, because the Lord your God will require it of you and you will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you do not make a vow at all, you will not be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever has passed from your lips you must be careful to do, because with your own mouth you vowed to make an offering to the Lord your God with your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come into your neighbor’s vineyard, you may eat grapes to satisfy your appetite, but you must not put any into your container.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come into a field of standing grain belonging to your neighbor and you pluck the heads of grain with your hand, you are not allowed to use a sickle to cut his standing grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man takes a woman and marries her, if she is not pleasing to him because he has found something indecent about her, and he writes her a divorce document and hands it to her and sends her out of his house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and she leaves and moves on and becomes the wife of another man,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then that second man hates her and writes her a divorce document and hands it to her and sends her out of his house, or perhaps the second man that took her as a wife dies,
speaker: Narrator

text: in these circumstances her first husband, who sent her away, cannot take her again as his wife after she was stigmatized as impure, because that would be detestable to the Lord. You must not attach guilt to the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man takes a new wife, he must not go out with the army, and no one is to impose any duty on him. He is to be freed from duty for one year for the sake of his homelife so that he may make the woman whom he has married happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: No person is to hold as security a mill or an upper millstone, because he would be holding someone’s livelihood as security.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man is caught kidnapping a fellow Israelite and enslaving him or selling him, that kidnapper must die, and you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful during an outbreak of an impure skin disease by being very conscientious about doing everything that the priests, who are Levites, instruct you to do. Take care to do exactly as I have commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam on your journey after coming out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a loan to your neighbor, a loan of any kind, do not go into his house to take his security pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stand outside, and the man to whom you are making the loan will bring the pledged object out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he is a poor man, do not sleep in a garment he has pledged as security.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are certainly to return the pledged object to him at sundown so he can sleep in his garment and bless you. Righteousness will be yours before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not oppress a hired person who is poor and needy, whether he is one of your brother Israelites or one of the aliens who reside in your land inside your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each day, before the sun goes down, pay him his wages, because he is poor and his life depends on it. If you do not, he will cry out against you, and you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fathers are not to be put to death because of their sons, and sons are not to be put to death because of their fathers. Each man is to be put to death because of his own crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not neglect justice for an alien who lives among you or for a fatherless child, and do not take the clothing of a widow as a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were a slave in Egypt, but the Lord your God redeemed you from there. Therefore I am commanding you to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you harvest the crops in your field and you forget a bundle in the field, do not return to get it. It will be for the benefit of the resident alien, the fatherless, and the widow, so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything your hands do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you beat your olives off the tree, do not strip the boughs clean of olives. Some are to be left for the benefit of the alien, the fatherless, and the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you cut grapes from your vineyard, do not go over it again. Leave some for the benefit of the alien, the fatherless, and the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt. That is why I am commanding you to do this.
speaker: Narrator

text: When there is a dispute between men and they go to court and a verdict is reached, and they have acquitted the innocent person and convicted the guilty one,
speaker: Narrator

text: if the guilty one is to be flogged, the judge is to make him lie down, and he will order him to be flogged in his presence with the number of blows that is proportionate to his guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may have him struck forty times, but no more, so that your brother does not become degraded in your eyes by receiving a severe beating that goes beyond this number.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are not to muzzle an ox when it is threshing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When brothers live together and one of them dies without having children, the wife of the deceased brother is not to marry a stranger from outside the family. Her brother-in-law is to come and take her as his wife and perform for her the duty of a brother-in-law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn that she bears will be recognized as a son who carries on the name of his deceased brother, so his name will not be erased from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man does not want to marry his sister-in-law, his sister-in-law is to go to the city gate where the elders preside and say, “My brother-in-law refuses to establish a name in Israel for his brother. He does not want to perform the duty of a brother-in-law for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the elders of his city are to call him and talk to him. If he stands firm and says, “I do not want to marry her,”
speaker: Narrator

text: his sister-in-law is to approach him in the sight of the elders. She is to pull the sandal off his foot, spit in his face, and testify by saying, “This is what is done to the man who will not build up the house of his brother!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the name that he will go by in Israel is “the house of a man whose sandal was pulled off.”
speaker: Narrator

text: If two men are fighting each other, a man and his neighbor, and the wife of one comes up to rescue her husband from the hands of the one striking him, and she reaches out her hand and she grabs hold of his testicles,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are to cut off her hand. Your eye is not to look on her with compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not have two alternate sets of stone weights in your bag, larger and smaller.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not have alternate measures in your house, larger and smaller.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have a full and honest set of weights. You must have a full and honest set of measures, so that you may have a long life in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For anyone doing such things, anyone who acts dishonestly, is detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Amalekites, without any fear of God, did to you on your journey after you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember how they confronted you on the way, when you were weak and tired, and they cut off all the stragglers among you, the ones who were lagging behind.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God gives you rest from all your enemies that are around you in the land the Lord your God is giving you to possess as an inheritance, wipe away the memory of Amalek from under the heavens. Do not forget!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you as an inheritance, and you take possession of it and settle in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: take some of the first ripe produce that you harvest from the soil of the land that the Lord your God is giving you. Put it in a basket, and go to the place where the Lord your God will choose to establish his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the priest who is presiding at that time and say to him, “Today I declare before the Lord your God that I have come to the land that the Lord swore to our fathers to give to us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take the basket from your hand and set it down in front of the altar of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will respond and say in the presence of the Lord your God, “My father was a wandering Aramean. He went down to Egypt and lived there as an alien with just a few people, but there he became a great, strong, and populous nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians mistreated and afflicted us. They imposed hard labor on us.
speaker: Narrator

text: We cried out to the Lord, the God of our fathers, and the Lord heard our voice, and he saw our affliction, our labor, and oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong hand and an outstretched arm and with great awe-inspiring acts and signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought us to this place and gave us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now, look as I bring the firstfruits of the soil that you have given me, Lord.”
Then set the basket down before the Lord your God and bow down before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you, as well as the Levite and the alien who resides among you, will rejoice in all the good things that the Lord your God has given to you and your household.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have finished tithing a tenth of all your produce in the third year, the year of tithing, and you have given it to the Levite, the alien, the fatherless, and to the widow so that they may eat within the gates of your cities and be satisfied,
speaker: Narrator

text: then say before the Lord your God, “I have completely removed the holy portion from my house, and I have also given it to the Levite, the alien, the fatherless, and to the widow just as you have commanded me. I have neither transgressed nor forgotten your commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not eaten any of it while I was mourning, and I have not removed any of it while I was unclean or given any of it for the dead. I have obeyed the voice of the Lord my God. I have done just as you have commanded me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look down from your holy dwelling place, from the heavens, and bless your people Israel and the soil that you have given us, as you swore to our fathers, a land flowing with milk and honey.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God commands you this day to carry out these statutes and commandments, and to be careful to do them with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have declared today that the Lord is your God and that you will walk in his ways and keep his statutes and commandments and his ordinances and obey his voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has declared today, just as he promised you, that you are his treasured people who are to carry out all of his commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that he will set you up in praise, fame, and splendor, high above all the nations that he has made, and that you will be set apart as a holy people to the Lord your God, just as he promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and the elders of Israel gave the following orders to the people: Keep the entire set of commands that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time that you cross the Jordan into the land that the Lord your God is giving to you, set up large stones and coat them with lime plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write on them all the words of this law when you cross over to enter the land that the Lord your God is giving you, a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your fathers, promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you cross over the Jordan, set up these stones on Mount Ebal and coat them with lime plaster, as I am commanding you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build an altar there to the Lord your God, an altar made of stones. Do not shape them with an iron tool.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build the altar of the Lord your God with whole, uncut stones, and offer whole burnt offerings on it to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sacrifice fellowship offerings and eat there, and rejoice before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write clearly and carefully all of the words of this law on the stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses and the priests, who are Levites, also spoke the following to all Israel:
Be silent and listen, Israel! Today you have become the people of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey the voice of the Lord your God and carry out his commandments and statutes that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses gave this command to the people that day:
speaker: Narrator

text: The following tribes will stand on Mount Gerizim to bless the people when you cross the Jordan: Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following will stand on Mount Ebal for the curse: Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites will testify to every person of Israel with a loud voice:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is the man that makes a carved image or a molten metal image, an abomination to the Lord, a work of the hands of a craftsman, and sets it up secretly.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who dishonors his father or his mother.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who moves the boundary marker of his neighbor.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who leads astray a blind man on his way.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who perverts the justice due to an alien who resides among you, or justice due to the fatherless or a widow.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is any man who lies down with his father’s wife, because he has removed the skirt that is reserved for his father.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who lies down with any animal.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is any man who lies down with his sister, either the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is any man who lies down with his mother-in-law.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who strikes down his neighbor secretly.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who takes payment to strike down an innocent person.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cursed is anyone who does not uphold the words of this law by doing them.
    All the people will say, “Amen!”
speaker: Narrator

text: If you fully obey the voice of the Lord your God by carefully carrying out all his commandments that I am giving you today, then the Lord your God will set you high above all the nations of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the following blessings will come upon you and overtake you, if you listen to the voice of the Lord your God:
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed in the city and blessed in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed in the fruit of your womb, in the fruit of your soil, and in the fruit of your animals: the calves of your cattle and the lambs of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed in your basket and in your kneading trough.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed when you come in, and you will be blessed when you go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause your enemies who rise up against you to be defeated before you. From one direction they will come out against you, but they will flee from you in seven directions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will command a blessing on you in your storehouses and in regard to every action of your hand, and he will bless you in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will establish you as his holy people, just as he swore to you, if you keep the commandments of the Lord your God and you walk in his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people of the earth will see that the name of the Lord has been proclaimed over you, and they will fear you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause you to be overflowing with good things: with the fruit of your womb, the fruit of your animals, and the fruit of the soil of the land that the Lord swore to your fathers to give you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will open for you his good storehouse, the heavens, by giving rain for your land in its season and by blessing all the work of your hand.
Then you will cause many nations to borrow from you, but you yourself will not borrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will make you the head and not the tail, and you will be only at the top and never at the bottom, if you conscientiously obey the commandments of the Lord your God that I am commanding you today to carry out,
speaker: Narrator

text: and if you do not turn away to the right or to the left from all the words that I am commanding you today, to walk after other gods and serve them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do not listen to the voice of the Lord your God and do not carefully carry out all of his commandments and statutes that I am commanding you today, then all these curses will come upon you and overtake you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed in the city, and you will be cursed in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed in your basket and in your kneading trough.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed in the fruit of your womb and in the fruit of your soil, in the calves of your cattle and in the lambs of your flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be cursed when you come in, and you will be cursed when you go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send on you a curse and confusion and opposition in every undertaking of your hand that you carry out, until you are destroyed and until you quickly perish, because of the evil you have done by forsaking me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause epidemics to cling to you until he has removed you from your land that you are going to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with wasting diseases, fever, and inflammation, with intense heat and with drought, and with blight and with mildew. They will pursue you until you perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The skies over your head will become bronze, and the earth under you will become iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will turn the rain of your land to dust. From the heavens it will come down on you until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cause you to be defeated before your enemies. In one direction you will go out against them, but in seven directions you will flee from them, and you will become a horrible sight to all the kingdoms of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your dead bodies will become food for every bird of the sky and every animal of the earth, and there will not be anyone to scare them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with the boils of Egypt, with tumors, scabs, and itch, from which you cannot be healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with insanity and with blindness and with a confused mind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will grope at noon as a blind person gropes in the dark, and you will not prosper in your ways.
You will be cheated and robbed all the time, and there will be no one to rescue you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be pledged in marriage to a woman, but another man will violate her.
You will build a house, but you will not live in it. You will plant a vineyard, but you will not enjoy its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ox will be slaughtered in front of your eyes, but you will not eat of it. Your donkey will be seized right in front of your face, and it will not return to you. Your flock will be given to your enemies, but there will be no one to help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your sons and your daughters will be given to another people, and your eyes will grow weak as you look longingly for them all day long, but your hands will be powerless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A people that you do not know will eat what your soil and all your work produces.
You will be squeezed and crushed throughout the days
speaker: Narrator

text: until you go insane from the sights that your eyes will see.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you on your knees and legs with distressing boils from which you cannot be healed, from the sole of your foot to the crown of your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will lead you and the king, whom you will set over you, to a nation that you and your fathers have not known, and there you will serve other gods of wood and stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will become an object of horror, the subject of proverbs, and the butt of sarcastic taunts among all the people to whom the Lord will send you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will take a lot of seed out to the field, but you will harvest little, because locusts will finish it off.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will plant and tend vineyards, but you will not drink the wine and store it, because worms will eat them up.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have olive trees covering your whole property, but you will not anoint yourselves with oil, because your olives will fall off the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will produce sons and daughters, but they will not remain yours, because they will go into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Locusts will take possession of all of your trees and all the fruit of your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The alien who resides among you will ascend higher and higher over you, and you will descend lower and lower.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will cause you to borrow, but you will not cause him to borrow. He will become the head, and you will become the tail.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these curses will come upon you, and they will pursue you and overtake you until you are destroyed, because you did not listen to the voice of the Lord your God by keeping his commandments and his statutes that he commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be signs and wonders against you and your descendants perpetually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you would not serve the Lord your God with joy and gladness in your heart flowing from the abundance of everything he gave you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you will serve your enemies that the Lord will unleash against you in hunger and thirst, in nakedness and a lack of everything, and he will put an iron yoke on your neck until he has destroyed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will bring a nation from far away against you, from the end of the earth, as fast as an eagle soars through the air, a nation whose language you do not understand,
speaker: Narrator

text: a fierce nation that does not show any regard for the old or any mercy to the young.
speaker: Narrator

text: That nation will eat the produce from your animals and the fruit from your soil until you are destroyed. It will leave you no grain, no new wine, no fresh oil, no calves of your cattle or lambs from your flock until it has caused you to perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: That nation will besiege you in all of your cities until the high, fortified walls that you were trusting collapse throughout your land. When that nation besieges you in all of the cities throughout your whole land that the Lord your God is giving you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you will eat the fruit of your womb, the flesh of your sons and daughters, whom the Lord your God has given you, because of the siege and distress that your enemy will inflict on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most sensitive and refined man among you will be so begrudging against his brother, against the wife he embraces, and against any of his children who still survive,
speaker: Narrator

text: that he will not give to any one of them some of the flesh of his children that he is eating, because then he would have nothing left for himself, because of the siege and distress that your enemy will inflict on you in all of your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most sensitive and refined woman among you, so refined and sensitive that she would not venture to touch the sole of her foot to the ground, will begrudge the husband she embraces and her son and daughter
speaker: Narrator

text: the afterbirth that goes out from between her legs and the babies that she gives birth to, because she plans to eat them secretly since she has nothing else, as a result of the siege and the distress that your enemy will inflict on you in all of your cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you are not careful to carry out all the words of this law that are written in this book, to fear this honored and awesome Name, the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will bring extraordinary plagues on you and your descendants: severe, long-lasting plagues and distressing, long-lasting sicknesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will bring back on you all the sicknesses of Egypt that you feared, and they will cling to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: More than that, the Lord will bring on you all other sicknesses and plagues that are not written in this Book of the Law, until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will be left as just a few people instead of being as numerous as the stars in the heavens, because you did not listen to the voice of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the Lord delighted in making you prosperous and making you many in number, likewise the Lord will delight in causing you to perish and in destroying you. You will be torn away from your land that you are going to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will scatter you among all the peoples from one end of the earth to the other, and there you will serve other gods, gods made of wood and stone, gods that you and your fathers have not known.
speaker: Narrator

text: Still, among those nations you will find no peace, nor will the sole of your foot find a place to rest. There the Lord will give you a trembling heart and longing eyes and a despairing soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your life will be hung out in front of you. Night and day you will live in dread, and you will not expect to survive.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you will say, “If only it were evening!” In the evening you will say, “If only it were morning!” because of the dread you feel in your heart and because of what your eyes see.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send you back to Egypt in ships on a journey that I said you would never again experience. There you will try to sell yourselves to your enemies as male and female slaves, but there will be no buyer.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the words of the covenant that the Lord commanded Moses to make with the people of Israel in the land of Moab, in addition to the covenant that he had made with them at Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses summoned all Israel and spoke to them as follows:
You have seen everything that the Lord did before your eyes in the land of Egypt, to Pharaoh, to all his officials, and to his whole land:
speaker: Narrator

text: the great trials that your eyes saw, those great signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord to this very day has not given you a heart to understand, or eyes to see, or ears to hear.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I led you through the wilderness for forty years. Your clothing did not wear out on you, nor did the sandals on your feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You did not eat bread, and you did not drink wine and beer. I did all this so you would know that I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When you came to this place, and Sihon king of Heshbon and Og king of Bashan came out to meet us in battle, we struck them down.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took their land and gave it as an inheritance to the Reubenites, the Gadites, and half of the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you are to keep the words of this covenant and carry them out so that you may succeed in all that you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are standing today before the Lord your God, all of you—your tribal heads, your elders, your officers, and men of every rank in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: your children, your wives, and the aliens who reside in your camp, whether as wood cutters or water carriers.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are standing here so that you may enter into the covenant of the Lord your God, which is sealed by the oath that the Lord your God is making with you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: in order to establish you today as his people and himself as your God, just as he promised you and just as he swore to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Today I am not making this covenant and its oath only with you,
speaker: Narrator

text: but also with everyone who is standing here with us before the Lord our God, and also with those who are not here with us today.
speaker: Narrator

text: You yourselves know how we lived in the land of Egypt and how we passed through the midst of the various nations we encountered.
speaker: Narrator

text: You saw their detestable things and their filthy idols of wood and stone and silver and gold that were with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make sure that there is not among you a man, a woman, a family, or a tribe whose heart today is turning away from the Lord our God to go and serve the gods of those nations. Make sure that there is among you no root that is producing a poison plant and bitter wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text: When such a person hears the words of this oath, he might congratulate himself in his heart and say, “I’ll be safe, even though I’m proceeding in my stubborn way.” By acting this way he will destroy the watered ground as well as the parched.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will not be willing to forgive him, but rather the anger and jealousy of the Lord will smoke against that man, and all the curses written in this document will come to rest on him, and the Lord will wipe away his name from under the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will single him out from all the tribes of Israel for disaster, in keeping with all the curses of the covenant that are written in this Book of the Law.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the next generation, your children who will come after your time, and the foreigner who will come from a distant land have seen the plagues on that land and the sicknesses with which the Lord struck it, they will say,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Sulfur and salt, conflagration for all of its land! No planting, no sprouting, no maturing crop in it! It will be like the overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the Lord overthrew in his fierce anger!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the nations will say, “Why did the Lord do something like that to this land? What is the reason for this burning, this fierce anger?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will say, “It is because they forsook the covenant of the Lord, the God of their fathers, which he made with them when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went and served other gods and bowed down to them, gods that they had not known and that he had not allotted to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the anger of the Lord burned against that land to bring on it the entire curse written in this book.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord uprooted them from their land in anger, in rage, and in his great wrath, and he hurled them into another land, as it is to this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The hidden things belong to the Lord our God, but the revealed things belong to us and to our children forever, so that we carry out all the words of this law.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all these things come upon you, both the blessing and the curse that I have given you, and you take them to heart while you are among all the nations to which the Lord your God has banished you,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when you return to the Lord your God and listen to his voice with all your heart and soul, in every way that I am commanding you today, you and your children,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord your God will restore you from your captivity. He will have compassion on you, and he will gather you together again out of all the peoples where the Lord your God has scattered you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if your banished people are at the end of the heavens, the Lord your God will gather you together there and take you away from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will bring you back to the land that your fathers possessed, and then you will possess it. He will make you more prosperous and numerous than your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, so that you love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul, with the result that you will live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord your God will place all these curses on your enemies and on those who hated you and persecuted you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again you will listen to the voice of the Lord, and you will carry out all of his commands that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will cause you to be overflowing with good things from all the work of your hands, in the fruit of your womb, in the fruit of your animals, and in the fruit of your soil. Once again he will rejoice over your prosperity, just as he rejoiced over your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text: when you obey the voice of the Lord your God by keeping his commandments and his statutes written in this Book of the Law, when you return to the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly, this commandment that I am giving you today is not too difficult for you, and it is not far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not up in the heavens, so that you have to say, “Which one of us will go up to the heavens and get it for us so we can listen to it and carry it out?”
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not across the sea, so that you have to say, “Which one of us will cross over to the other side of the sea and get it for us so we can listen to it and carry it out?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, the word is very near you. It is in your mouth and in your heart, so you can obey it.
speaker: Narrator

text: See now, today I have set before you life and prosperity, death and disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what I am commanding you today: Love the Lord your God, walk in his ways, and keep his commandments, his statutes, and his ordinances. Then you will live and increase in number, and the Lord your God will bless you in the land that you are going to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if your heart turns away, and you do not listen, and you are lured away, and you bow down to other gods and serve them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I declare to you today that you will most certainly perish. You will not live a long life on the land that you are about to enter and possess by crossing over the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: I call the heavens and the earth to witness against you today that I have set before you life and death, a blessing and a curse. Choose life so that you and your descendants may live
speaker: Narrator

text: by loving the Lord your God, by listening to his voice, and by clinging to him, because that means life for you, and you will live a long life on your land that the Lord swore to give to your fathers, to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses came and spoke the following words to all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to them:
“I am now one hundred twenty years old. I can no longer go out and come back. The Lord has said to me, ‘You will not cross over this Jordan.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God himself will cross over before you. He will destroy those nations before you, and you will take possession of their land. Joshua is the one who will cross over before you, as the Lord promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will do to them as he did to Sihon and Og, kings of the Amorites, and as he did to their lands when he destroyed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will hand them over to you, and you are to deal with them according to the whole set of commands that I gave you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid and do not be terrified before them, because the Lord your God is going with you. He will not abandon you and he will not forsake you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses called Joshua and said to him in the view of all Israel:
“Be strong and courageous, because you will go with this people into the land that the Lord promised to your fathers with an oath, and you will divide it among them as their possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord himself will go ahead of you. He will be with you. He will not abandon you, and he will not forsake you. Do not be afraid and do not be overwhelmed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses wrote down this law, and he gave it to the priests, the sons of Levi who carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, and to all the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses commanded them:
“At the end of seven years, at the appointed time of the year of the release, at the Festival of Shelters,
speaker: Narrator

text: when all Israel comes to appear in the presence of the Lord your God at the place that he will choose, you are to read this law before all Israel in their hearing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather the people—the men, the women, the children, and the alien who resides within your gates—so that they may hear it and learn to fear the Lord your God and to be careful to carry out all the words of this law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their children also, who do not know the law, are to hear it and learn to fear the Lord your God all the time that you live on the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord said to Moses, “The time is approaching for you to die. Summon Joshua and stand at the Tent of Meeting, and I will commission him.”
So Moses and Joshua went and stood at the Tent of Meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord appeared at the tent in a pillar of cloud, and the pillar of cloud stood over the entrance to the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to Moses:
“You are about to lie down with your fathers, but this people will rise up and prostitute themselves to the foreign gods among them in the land they are about to enter. They will forsake me and break my covenant that I made with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: My anger will burn against them on that day, and I will forsake them and hide my face from them. They will be on the verge of being devoured, and many evils and distresses will find them. They will say on that day, ‘Haven’t these evil things found us because our God is not among us?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet I will hide my face on that day because of all the evil they have done by turning to other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, write down this song and teach it to the people of Israel. Put it in their mouths so this song will be my witness against the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I bring them into the land flowing with milk and honey that I promised by oath to their fathers, and they eat and are satisfied and grow fat, and they then turn to other gods and serve them, when they despise me and break my covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text: and many evils and distresses find them, then this song will testify against them as a witness, because it will not be forgotten or gone from the mouths of their descendants. I certainly know the inclination that they are developing today before I bring them to the land that I have promised on oath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses wrote down this song on that day and taught it to the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord commissioned Joshua son of Nun and said to him:
“Be strong and courageous, because you will bring the people of Israel into the land that I have promised to them with an oath, and I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished writing the words of this law in a book,
speaker: Narrator

text: he gave this command to the Levites, who carry the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take this Book of the Law, and place it beside the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God, and let it remain there as a witness against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I certainly know how rebellious and stubborn you are. Even while I am still alive and among you today, you are rebels against the Lord. So how much more after my death!
speaker: Narrator

text: Assemble all the elders of your tribes and your officials before me, and I will speak all these words in their hearing, and I will call the heavens and the earth to witness against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that after my death you will act corruptly and turn from the way that I have commanded you, and that evil will come on you in future days when you do evil in the sight of the Lord by provoking him to anger by the work of your hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses spoke the words of this song in the hearing of the whole assembly of Israel, from beginning to end:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give ear, O heavens, and I will speak.
Let the earth hear the sayings from my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let my teaching drop down like rain,
and let my sayings distill like dew,
like raindrops on grass,
like showers on green plants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, I will proclaim the name of the Lord.
Ascribe greatness to our God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the Rock! Perfect is his work.
Indeed all of his ways are justice.
He is a faithful God. He does no wrong.
Righteous and upright is he.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Israel acted corruptly against him.
They are not his children.
That is their fault.
They are a twisted and crooked generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this how you repay the Lord,
you foolish people, who are not wise?
Is he not your father, who created you,
who made you and established you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the days of the distant past.
Consider the years of many generations.
Ask your father and he will tell you about it.
Ask your elders and they will describe it to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance,
when he separated the children of Adam,
he established the boundaries for peoples
    according to the number of the sons of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the allotment for the Lord is his people.
Jacob is the territory that is his possession.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord found Jacob in a wild land,
in a desolate land, in a howling wasteland.
He encircled him. He cared for him.
He guarded him like the pupil of his eye.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As an eagle rises from its nest
and hovers over its young,
then spreads its wings to catch them
and carries them on the edge of its wings,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so the Lord alone led Israel.
There was no foreign god with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He caused them to ride over the high places of the land,
and they ate the produce from the fields.
He caused them to suck honey from the rocks
and olive oil from the hardest flint.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He fed them with curds from the cattle and milk from the flocks,
with fat lambs, rams, and goats from Bashan,
with the very best wheat,
and they drank foaming wine, the blood of the grape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jeshurun grew fat and kicked.
You grew fat, you were stout, you were stuffed.
Then he abandoned the God who made him,
and he mocked the Rock who saved him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made him jealous with strange gods.
They provoked him with abominations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sacrificed to demons that are not gods,
to gods they had not known,
to newcomers from their neighbors,
gods whom your fathers did not fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You failed to remember the Rock who conceived you.
You forgot the God who gave you birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord saw this and rejected them,
because his sons and daughters had provoked him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the Lord said:
    I will hide my face from them,
    until I see what their final condition will be,
    because they are a twisted generation,
    children who cannot be trusted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have made me jealous with their non-gods.
They have provoked me with their useless things.
So I will make them jealous by a non-people.
By a foolish nation I will provoke them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a fire has been ignited by my anger,
and it burns to the depths of hell.
It devours the earth and its produce.
It sets the foundations of the mountains on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will pile up disasters for them.
I will use up all my arrows on them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will be sucked dry by hunger and burned up by fever.
I will send them bitter destruction.
Wild animals will sink their teeth into them
    with the burning venom of snakes that crawl in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the street the sword will take away their children.
Inside the houses terror will fill young man and
    young woman alike,
the nursing child, together with the gray-haired old man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would have said, “I will cut them to pieces.
I will erase their memory from mankind,”
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I had not dreaded the taunting of the enemy.
I did not want their adversaries to misunderstand.
I did not want them to say,
“Our hand is high-and-mighty,
and the Lord has not done any of this.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they are a nation that never takes advice,
and they understand nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only they had been wise,
they would have comprehended this.
They would have understood
what the final outcome would be.
speaker: Narrator

text:
